newsitem.title: USA: Global Marine says not agreed to lower rates.
newsitem.headline: Global Marine says not agreed to lower rates.

text.p: Global Marine Inc said that it had not agreed to lower dayrates for two jackup rigs under contract to Unocal Corp.

Shares in Global and other offshore drilling concerns declined earlier Thursday amid speculation that some exploration and production companies were balking at higher charges for rigs, especially shallow-water jackup rigs.

However, David Herasimchuk vice president in charge of marketing at Global, said over the telephone: "In neither case have we agreed lower dayrates. Global shares were down 1-5/8 to 26-1/4 in early afternoon, after falling as low as 25-5/8.
Of the two rigs, one would have a gap of 30 to 60 days between contracts, and the other was looking for a new contract, although both will be drilling to the end of this month, he said.
"We may have news on a contract for the second rig as early as tomorrow," Herasimchuk said.
He said talk of lower dayrates often hits the sector ahead of a Texas lease sale -- and one is approaching -- as companies prepare to bid on new leases.
"I think that this has nothing to do with project economics.... What is happening is operators are getting prepared for the Texas sale," he said.
The drop by drilling stocks was not confined to the jackup sector, but also hit those companies that concentrate on the deepwater.

"The story on jackups has been developing for a while and we have been cautious on that sector for some time, but all companies are being tarred with the same brush," Iain Smith of Eastgate Management said.

Among deepwater drillers, Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc was down 1-7/8 at 86-1/8, Atwood Oceanics Inc was off 2-15/16 at 82-1/2, having traded as low at 81-15/16, and Transocean Offshore was down 7/16 at 81-5/8, having traded as low as 79-1/8.
Among the jackup operators, Marine Drilling Cos Inc fell 1-1/15 at 20-13/16.
